sections.title: Dividend Reinvestment
sections.subtitle: Harness the power of compounding dividends

sections.title: The Eighth Wonder of the World
sections.content: Einstein allegedly called compound interest the eighth wonder of the world. Dividend reinvestment is compound interest on steroids—your dividends buy more shares, which pay more dividends, which buy more shares. Over decades, this snowball effect is transformative.

sections.title: How Dividend Reinvestment Works
sections.content:
When you reinvest dividends, instead of receiving cash, your dividends automatically purchase additional shares of the same stock or fund.

Example:
- You own 100 shares of a $50 stock with a 3% yield
- Annual dividend: $150 (100 shares × $50 × 3%)
- Reinvested: $150 buys 3 more shares
- Next year: 103 shares pay $154.50
- And so on...

Over 30 years, those reinvested dividends can more than double your share count, even without adding new money. Combined with dividend growth, your income can increase 10x or more.

sections.title: The Math of Compounding Dividends
sections.content:
Let's see the real impact with numbers:

Scenario: $100,000 invested in dividend stocks
- Starting yield: 3%
- Dividend growth: 7% annually
- Stock price growth: 5% annually

Without Reinvestment (Taking Cash):
- Year 1 income: $3,000
- Year 10 income: $5,900
- Year 20 income: $11,600
- Year 30 income: $22,800
- Total dividends received: $290,000
- Portfolio value: $432,000

With Reinvestment (DRIP):
- Year 1 income: $3,000 (reinvested)
- Year 10 income: $9,200 (reinvested)
- Year 20 income: $28,500 (reinvested)
- Year 30 income: $88,000 (if you stopped reinvesting)
- Portfolio value: $1,450,000

The difference is staggering. Reinvesting dividends for 30 years turns $100,000 into $1.45 million, with $88,000 in annual income. Taking cash leaves you with $432,000 and $22,800 in income.

points.title: Brokerage DRIP
points.description: Most brokers offer free automatic dividend reinvestment. Enable it in your account settings. Dividends buy fractional shares of the same stock. Simple and effective.

points.title: Company DRIP
points.description: Some companies offer direct DRIP programs, sometimes with discounts (1-5% off share price). Requires more paperwork but can save money on large positions.

points.title: Selective Reinvestment
points.description: Instead of automatic DRIP, collect dividends as cash and manually invest in your most undervalued holdings. More work but allows strategic rebalancing.

points.title: Hybrid Approach
points.description: DRIP during accumulation phase, then switch to cash dividends in retirement when you need income. Most investors should DRIP until they need the income.

sections.title: When to DRIP vs. Take Cash
sections.content:
DRIP (Reinvest) When:
- You're in the accumulation phase (building wealth)
- You don't need the income for living expenses
- You're investing in tax-advantaged accounts (IRA, 401k)
- You want to maximize long-term growth

Take Cash When:
- You're retired and need income
- You want to rebalance by investing dividends elsewhere
- The stock is overvalued and you'd rather buy something cheaper
- You need liquidity for emergencies

Most investors should DRIP until retirement, then gradually switch to cash dividends as they need income.

sections.title: Tax Consideration
sections.content: In taxable accounts, you owe taxes on dividends whether you reinvest or take cash. DRIP doesn't defer taxes. Consider holding dividend stocks in tax-advantaged accounts (IRA, 401k) to avoid annual tax drag.

sections.title: Maximizing Dividend Compounding
steps: Enable DRIP in your brokerage account for all dividend positions
Prioritize dividend stocks in tax-advantaged accounts (IRA, 401k)
Focus on dividend growth stocks—7% annual dividend growth doubles income every 10 years
Reinvest for as long as possible—time is the key ingredient
Add new money regularly to accelerate the compounding effect
Don't interrupt compounding by selling during market dips
Track your dividend income growth annually to stay motivated

sections.title: The Dividend Snowball in Action
sections.content:
Here's how a real dividend snowball might grow:

Year 1: $500/month invested, 3% yield = $180 annual dividends
Year 5: $30,000 portfolio, $1,100 annual dividends
Year 10: $75,000 portfolio, $3,200 annual dividends
Year 15: $150,000 portfolio, $7,500 annual dividends
Year 20: $280,000 portfolio, $15,000 annual dividends
Year 25: $500,000 portfolio, $30,000 annual dividends
Year 30: $850,000 portfolio, $55,000 annual dividends

By year 30, your dividends alone ($55,000/year) exceed your total annual contributions ($6,000/year). The snowball is now self-sustaining.

sections.title: Key Takeaway
sections.content: Dividend reinvestment is the secret weapon of wealthy dividend investors. The earlier you start and the longer you reinvest, the more powerful the compounding effect. Be patient, stay consistent, and let time do the heavy lifting.

sections.title: Next Steps
sections.content: You now understand the power of dividend reinvestment. In the next lesson, we'll cover the tax implications of dividend investing and strategies to minimize your tax burden.
